description.short: Measures the degree to which organizations unconsciously recreate the same security failures, attack scenarios, or crisis patterns despite conscious awareness that these patterns cause harm
description.context: Repetition compulsion represents an unconscious psychological drive to repeat familiar vulnerability patterns even when alternative, safer behaviors are known and available. This goes beyond simple habit formation or procedural errors‚Äîorganizations unconsciously seek familiar patterns of vulnerability because they feel psychologically safer than unknown security states. Sophisticated attackers identify and exploit these predictable repetition cycles.
description.impact: Organizations exhibiting repetition compulsion experience clustering of similar security incidents across time, particularly around anniversary dates of past failures. This creates predictable vulnerability windows that advanced persistent threats systematically exploit through temporal pattern recognition and attack timing strategies. Despite conscious intentions to improve, organizations unconsciously recreate the same incident response failures, vendor selection mistakes, and resource allocation patterns.
description.psychological_basis: Freud's 'Beyond the Pleasure Principle' (1920) established repetition compulsion as fundamental to human psychology, where individuals unconsciously recreate traumatic situations in attempts to master them. Klein's object relations theory (1946) demonstrates how early relational patterns repeat in organizational contexts. Jung's concept of complexes (1969) explains how unconscious psychological structures perpetuate repetitive behavior patterns. Neuroscience research on neural pathway reinforcement shows that repeated patterns create stronger synaptic connections, making familiar behaviors easier to activate than novel alternatives.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 √ó Quick_Assessment + w2 √ó Conversation_Depth + w3 √ó Red_Flags) √ó Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Pattern Disruption Active
green.description: Organization has systematic processes to identify and break repetitive failure patterns, with documented evidence of successfully implementing lessons learned. Measurable improvement in incident diversity over time. Less than 15% of incidents involve repeated root causes. No significant correlation between incident timing and organizational anniversary dates.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Intermittent Recognition
yellow.description: Organization occasionally recognizes repetitive patterns and has some processes to address them, but implementation is inconsistent. Similar incident types occur periodically (15-35% repetition rate). Some correlation between incident timing and organizational patterns. Partial implementation of past lessons learned.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Unconscious Repetition Active
red.description: Organization shows clear patterns of repeated security failures with similar root causes (35%+ repetition rate). Minimal implementation of past lessons learned. Strong correlation between incident timing and organizational anniversary dates. Decision-making patterns consistently mirror past decisions that led to security failures.

repetition_compulsion_index.description: Cyclic pattern analysis using Discrete Fourier Transform to identify repetitive frequencies in security incident patterns
repetition_compulsion_index.interpretation: Higher values indicate stronger unconscious repetition of security failure patterns across time

pattern_persistence_measure.description: Measures persistence of historical incident patterns in current security behavior with exponential time decay
pattern_persistence_measure.interpretation: Higher scores indicate stronger persistence of past failure patterns in current operations

unconscious_resistance_function.description: Ratio of attempted security improvements to successful implementations multiplied by pattern recurrence
unconscious_resistance_function.interpretation: Values > 2 indicate strong unconscious resistance to breaking repetitive failure patterns

detection_threshold.interpretation: Binary detection triggers when repetition compulsion index exceeds 3 and unconscious resistance exceeds 2

RC_i.calculation: Repetition compulsion index via DFT analysis of incident patterns
RC_i.query: Analyze incident_type and root_cause frequency patterns across 36-month timeline using FFT to identify repetitive cycles

PP.calculation: Pattern persistence measuring similarity between current and historical incident patterns
PP.query: SELECT AVG(similarity_score) FROM current_incidents JOIN historical_incidents ON pattern_match WHERE time_weighted=true

UR.calculation: Unconscious resistance from ratio of attempted to successful security changes
UR.query: SELECT (COUNT(change_requests) / COUNT(completed_changes)) * recurrence_rate FROM security_improvements WHERE timeframe='12_months'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Security Incident Pattern Repetition
items.question: How many times in the past 3 years has your organization experienced security incidents that involved similar root causes or failure points? Provide specific examples of repeated incident types.

options.label: Less than 15% of incidents involve repeated root causes; diverse incident portfolio with documented pattern analysis showing variety
15-35% of incidents involve similar root causes; some repetitive patterns but also incident diversity
More than 35% of incidents involve repeated root causes; clear pattern of recreating the same security failures

items.evidence_required: 36-month incident history with root cause analysis, pattern similarity assessment, statistical clustering analysis

items.title: Lessons Learned Implementation Rate
items.question: When you conduct post-incident reviews, how often do the recommended improvements from previous incidents get fully implemented before the next similar incident occurs? Provide recent examples.

options.label: 80% or more of post-incident recommendations fully implemented within 90 days; documented tracking and verification
50-80% of recommendations implemented, sometimes with delays; mixed implementation record
Less than 50% of recommendations implemented before similar incidents recur; recommendations documented but not executed

items.evidence_required: Post-incident review recommendations with implementation status, timeline tracking, verification evidence

items.title: Historical Decision Pattern Analysis
items.question: What's your process for checking whether current security decisions mirror past decisions that led to problems? Tell us about a time when you caught yourselves repeating a past mistake.

options.label: Mandatory decision genealogy process requiring comparison to historical decisions; documented examples of pattern interruption
Occasional consideration of historical decisions but no systematic process; ad-hoc pattern recognition
No systematic process to check current decisions against historical patterns; decisions made independently of history

items.evidence_required: Decision documentation process, historical comparison requirements, examples of decision pattern analysis

items.title: Anniversary Incident Correlation
items.question: How do you handle security incidents that occur around anniversary dates of previous major security events or organizational changes? Describe any patterns you've noticed in incident timing.

options.label: No significant correlation between incident timing and organizational anniversary dates; statistical analysis confirms randomness
Occasional clustering around anniversary dates but not consistent; some temporal patterns observed
Clear correlation between incidents and anniversary dates of past events; statistically significant temporal clustering

items.evidence_required: Incident timing analysis, anniversary date identification, statistical correlation assessment
items.soc_mapping: Temporal pattern analysis from incident_date correlations

items.title: Vendor Selection Pattern Avoidance
items.question: When selecting new security vendors, tools, or procedures, what's your process for ensuring you don't recreate past vendor/tool problems? Give an example from the last year.

options.label: Mandatory evaluation against characteristics of past problematic vendors; documented assessment preventing pattern repetition
Informal consideration of past vendor issues but no systematic prevention process; lessons partially applied
No systematic process to avoid repeating past vendor selection mistakes; vendor decisions made independently of history

items.evidence_required: Vendor selection criteria documentation, historical pattern analysis requirements, recent vendor selection with comparison analysis

items.title: Crisis Response Pattern Repetition
items.question: During crisis situations, how often does your organization revert to communication and decision-making patterns that previously proved ineffective? Describe your most recent crisis response.

options.label: Crisis responses show clear evolution from past patterns; documented use of alternative communication and decision approaches
Some repetition of past crisis response patterns but also new approaches; inconsistent pattern breaking
Crisis responses consistently mirror past ineffective patterns; same communication failures and decision delays recur

items.evidence_required: Crisis response documentation from multiple incidents, pattern comparison analysis, communication flow records

items.title: Resource Allocation Pattern Analysis
items.question: What mechanisms do you have to ensure security resource allocation decisions avoid repeating past budgeting mistakes? Describe a recent security budget decision and how you evaluated it against historical patterns.

options.label: Formal budget review process requiring comparison to historical allocation patterns and outcomes; documented analysis of past allocation effectiveness
Informal consideration of past budgeting decisions but no systematic evaluation; lessons partially incorporated
No systematic evaluation of budget decisions against historical patterns; allocation decisions made independently of past outcomes

items.evidence_required: Budget planning documentation, historical allocation analysis, outcome correlation assessment

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

subsections.title: Opening Questions: Pattern Recognition and History

items.text: Walk me through your security incident history over the past 3 years. What patterns do you notice when you look at root causes, failure modes, and timing of incidents?

scoring_guidance.green: Can articulate specific patterns with data, has conducted formal pattern analysis, shows awareness of repetitive elements and has taken action to break cycles
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness that some incidents seem similar but no systematic pattern analysis, vague sense of repetition without specifics
scoring_guidance.red: No awareness of repetitive patterns, describes each incident as unique, defensive when asked about similarities to past incidents

followups.text: Show me your incident database - can we run a query to identify incidents with similar root causes across different time periods?
Have you noticed any correlation between incident timing and significant organizational dates - anniversaries of past incidents, leadership changes, or major events?

items.text: Tell me about your post-incident review process. What happens to the recommendations from these reviews - how many actually get implemented, and how do you track that?

scoring_guidance.green: Formal tracking of recommendations with implementation timelines, can show specific examples of recommendations implemented before similar incidents, metrics on implementation rates
scoring_guidance.yellow: Post-incident reviews conducted but implementation tracking is informal, some recommendations implemented with delays, inconsistent follow-through
scoring_guidance.red: Post-incident reviews are perfunctory exercises, recommendations documented but rarely implemented, same issues identified repeatedly without remediation

followups.text: Show me the last 5 post-incident review reports - how many of those recommendations were fully implemented within 90 days?
Have you ever had a security incident where the post-incident review said 'this is the same thing that happened in [previous incident]'? What was done differently that time?

items.text: How do you make major security decisions - tool selection, vendor choices, architecture changes? Do you have a process for checking whether a decision you're about to make is similar to a past decision that didn't work out?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic decision genealogy process requiring historical comparison, documented examples of decisions modified based on historical analysis, formal requirement to consult past decision outcomes
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal consideration of past decisions, some discussion of 'what we tried before' but no systematic process, inconsistent use of historical information
scoring_guidance.red: Decisions made without reference to history, 'this time will be different' rationalization, no formal process to compare current decisions to past patterns

followups.text: Walk me through your most recent major security technology decision - did anyone ask 'have we tried something like this before and how did it work out'?
Do you maintain any kind of decision log that would let you look back and see what you decided in similar situations previously?

items.text: Describe your last major security crisis. How did your team respond - what communication patterns, decision-making approaches, and escalation processes did you use? How did that compare to previous crisis responses?

scoring_guidance.green: Can articulate clear differences between current and past crisis responses, shows evidence of learning and adaptation, documented evolution in crisis management approaches
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some awareness that crisis responses seem familiar but limited comparison to past events, mixed record of applying lessons from previous crises
scoring_guidance.red: Crisis responses show identical patterns to past events including same communication failures and decision delays, 'we always do it this way in a crisis' attitude

followups.text: Show me crisis communication logs from this incident and one from 12-18 months ago - do we see similar communication breakdown patterns?
During the crisis, did anyone say something like 'this feels like what happened last time'? What was done differently if so?

items.text: Tell me about your vendor and technology selection process. When you look at vendors you've had problems with in the past, do you see any common characteristics? How do you avoid selecting vendors with those same characteristics again?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic analysis of past vendor issues with documented characteristic patterns, selection criteria explicitly designed to avoid repeating past mistakes, evidence of vendor selection pattern breaking
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of past vendor problems but no systematic prevention approach, informal 'let's not make that mistake again' without structured processes
scoring_guidance.red: Pattern of selecting vendors with similar characteristics to past problematic relationships, rationalization that 'this vendor is different' despite similar profile

followups.text: Show me your vendor issue history - can we identify patterns in the types of vendors or relationships that create problems?
Walk me through your most recent vendor selection - did anyone compare this vendor to past vendors you've had issues with?

items.text: How does your organization talk about past security incidents and failures? Are these events used as learning opportunities, or do they tend to get minimized, forgotten, or rationalized?

scoring_guidance.green: Past incidents actively referenced in planning and decision-making, organizational memory preserved through documentation and storytelling, failures treated as valuable learning data
scoring_guidance.yellow: Selective memory of past incidents, some events remembered and referenced but others forgotten or minimized, inconsistent use of historical lessons
scoring_guidance.red: Organizational amnesia about past incidents, active minimization or rationalization of past failures, resistance to discussing historical problems

followups.text: Ask three different team members about your major security incident from 18 months ago - do they remember it the same way and reference the same lessons learned?
How do you onboard new security team members about past incidents - is there a 'history of what we've learned' curriculum or documentation?

items.text: When you try to implement security improvements based on lessons learned, what resistance do you encounter? How often do improvement initiatives stall out or revert to previous approaches?

scoring_guidance.green: Security improvements implemented with organizational support, low reversion rate, documented success in changing processes that previously failed, metrics showing sustained change
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed success in implementing improvements, some resistance and occasional reversion to familiar patterns, partial implementation common
scoring_guidance.red: Strong resistance to security changes, high reversion rate to 'the way we've always done it', improvement initiatives consistently stall or get scaled back to familiar approaches

followups.text: Give me an example of a security process improvement that was implemented, worked for a while, but then gradually reverted to the old way of doing things. What drove that reversion?
How do you measure whether security improvements are sustained over time, or do you just assume they stay in place once implemented?

subsections.title: Probing for Red Flags
subsections.description: Unconscious repetition compulsion indicators that signal systematic pattern recreation

items.label: "We seem to keep experiencing the same types of incidents, but each time we think it's just bad luck or coincidence..."
Post-incident recommendations are documented but implementation consistently stalls, with same issues appearing in multiple incident reviews
"This time will be different" or "We've learned our lesson" statements followed by repeated similar failures
Security incidents cluster around anniversary dates of past major incidents, organizational changes, or leadership transitions
Pattern of selecting vendors or technologies with similar characteristics to past problematic choices despite conscious intentions to change
Crisis responses show identical communication breakdowns and decision-making delays across multiple incidents
"We're comfortable with how we've always done it" resistance to security improvements even when past approaches demonstrably failed

solutions.title: Historical Pattern Analysis System
solutions.description: Implement automated tools that analyze incident data for repetitive patterns across time, root causes, and organizational triggers, with statistical analysis flagging when current decisions or configurations mirror past failure conditions
solutions.implementation: Deploy pattern recognition software that maintains multi-year incident database with root cause taxonomy. Implement statistical analysis algorithms using Discrete Fourier Transform to identify cyclic patterns. Create automated alerts when incident patterns match historical failures. Include anniversary date monitoring that increases vigilance during historically significant periods. Generate quarterly pattern analysis reports with trend visualization.
solutions.technical_controls: Machine learning pattern recognition, statistical analysis software, incident database with taxonomic classification, automated alerting system, temporal correlation analysis tools
solutions.roi: 340% average within 18 months through early pattern recognition and prevention of repetitive failures
solutions.timeline: 90-120 days for full deployment and baseline establishment

solutions.title: Decision Genealogy Tracking System
solutions.description: Create systematic documentation processes that trace current security decisions back to previous similar decisions and their outcomes, with mandatory historical parallel analysis for major decisions
solutions.implementation: Establish decision documentation requirements capturing decision rationale, alternatives considered, and historical precedents. Create decision review boards that specifically evaluate whether proposed solutions avoid repeating past mistakes. Implement searchable decision database enabling comparison of current decisions to historical patterns. Require 'historical impact statement' for all major security decisions documenting lessons from similar past decisions. Track decision outcomes to build institutional learning database.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision management system, searchable historical database, workflow automation for review requirements, outcome tracking analytics
solutions.roi: 280% average within 12 months through improved decision quality and pattern avoidance

solutions.title: Incident Response Pattern Breaking Protocols
solutions.description: Develop alternative incident response procedures specifically designed to break past response patterns, with response team rotation and structured decision frameworks
solutions.implementation: Create multiple incident response playbooks with different communication and escalation patterns. Implement response team rotation policies preventing same personnel from handling similar incident types. Establish structured decision-making frameworks that force consideration of non-historical response options. Deploy crisis communication circuit breakers that activate when internal patterns match past communication failures. Include external facilitators for incidents showing pattern similarity to past failures. Conduct response simulations focusing on alternative approaches.
solutions.technical_controls: Incident response management platform, team scheduling and rotation system, structured decision frameworks, pattern recognition alerting
solutions.roi: 320% average within 12 months through improved incident response effectiveness and reduced recurrence

solutions.title: Vendor and Technology Selection Pattern Controls
solutions.description: Establish vendor selection criteria that specifically evaluate whether potential vendors exhibit characteristics similar to past problematic relationships, with technology evaluation preventing repetitive tool selection mistakes
solutions.implementation: Develop vendor assessment framework identifying characteristics of past problematic vendor relationships. Create vendor evaluation scorecard explicitly checking for similarity to historical issues. Implement vendor performance pattern analysis flagging repetitive relationship problems. Establish technology selection process requiring comparison to past tool failures. Maintain vendor relationship database tracking issue patterns across vendors. Require diversity in vendor selection approaches to prevent pattern repetition.
solutions.technical_controls: Vendor management platform with historical analysis, automated characteristic matching, performance tracking database, evaluation workflow system
solutions.roi: 260% average within 18 months through improved vendor selection and relationship management
solutions.timeline: 60-75 days for framework development and implementation

solutions.title: Crisis Communication Circuit Breakers
solutions.description: Design crisis communication protocols that include automatic escalation to external facilitators when internal patterns match past communication failures, with communication diversity requirements
solutions.implementation: Establish crisis communication protocols with built-in pattern interrupt triggers. Define communication failure signatures from past incidents. Implement automatic escalation when current crisis communication matches historical failure patterns. Create communication diversity requirements forcing use of different channels and decision-makers during crises. Pre-authorize external crisis facilitators who can intervene when pattern repetition detected. Develop crisis communication alternatives to standard organizational patterns. Include post-crisis analysis comparing current to historical communication patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Crisis communication platform, pattern matching algorithms, automated escalation systems, multi-channel communication tools
solutions.roi: 290% average within 12 months through improved crisis response and stakeholder management
solutions.timeline: 30-45 days for protocol development and authorization

solutions.title: Resource Allocation History Integration
solutions.description: Develop budgeting processes that systematically evaluate proposed resource allocations against historical allocation patterns and their security outcomes, with diversity metrics
solutions.implementation: Create budget review process requiring historical pattern analysis for all security resource allocation decisions. Establish budget committees including members with historical pattern analysis expertise. Implement resource allocation diversity metrics encouraging varied approaches to security investments. Develop correlation analysis linking past resource allocation decisions to security outcomes. Require justification when budget allocations mirror past patterns that led to failures. Track multi-year allocation patterns with effectiveness measurement. Include external budget review for major allocation decisions showing strong similarity to historical patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Budget management system with historical analytics, correlation analysis tools, diversity metrics tracking, outcome measurement dashboards
solutions.roi: 310% average within 18 months through optimized resource allocation and reduced wasteful repetition
solutions.timeline: 45-60 days for process development and integration with budget cycles

risk_scenarios.title: Temporal Exploitation Attack - Anniversary-Based Targeting
risk_scenarios.description: Advanced attackers analyze organizational incident history, identify repetition patterns, and time attacks to coincide with predictable vulnerability windows such as budget planning periods or anniversary dates of past incidents
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: APT group maps 36-month incident history, identifies that organization experiences email security failures during Q4 budget planning. Launches sophisticated spear-phishing campaign during exact timeframe when organization's unconscious patterns create maximum vulnerability.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Repetition compulsion creates predictable temporal windows when organization unconsciously recreates familiar vulnerability patterns. Attackers exploit anniversary reactions and stress-induced regression to past dysfunctional responses.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations experiencing repeated holiday season breaches due to unconscious recreation of reduced staffing and relaxed procedures during same annual periods

risk_scenarios.title: Pattern Recognition APT Campaign - Multi-Stage Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Sophisticated threat actors analyze organization's incident response history, design multi-stage attacks that exploit tendency to repeat the same defensive mistakes at each stage
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Threat actor reviews publicly disclosed incidents and breach reports, identifies organization's repetitive response patterns including predictable communication delays and escalation failures. Designs attack sequence specifically triggering these familiar but ineffective response patterns at each stage.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizations unconsciously revert to familiar incident response patterns even when these patterns previously failed. Attackers create attack sequences deliberately triggering organization's repetition compulsion, causing predictable ineffective responses.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: APT groups observing that target organization consistently delays executive notification during initial incident stages, designing attacks with multiple stages timed to exploit these predictable delays

risk_scenarios.title: Authority Manipulation Cycle - Repeated Social Engineering
risk_scenarios.description: Threat actors identify and exploit organization's tendency to repeat past authority-based security failures through social engineering attacks recreating same dysfunctional authority relationships
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Attackers analyze past BEC incidents affecting organization, identify that employees consistently comply with urgent requests from apparent executives without verification. Execute multiple waves of CEO fraud using identical psychological patterns knowing organization will repeat past compliance behaviors.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizations unconsciously maintain dysfunctional authority dynamics that previously led to security failures. Repetition compulsion causes employees to respond to authority manipulation identically across multiple incidents despite conscious awareness of the pattern.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations experiencing multiple BEC incidents with identical social engineering patterns exploiting same authority compliance vulnerabilities each time

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Relationship Pattern Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers compromise vendors with characteristics similar to past problematic vendor relationships, knowing organization unconsciously selects and trusts vendors matching familiar but vulnerable patterns
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Threat actor identifies that organization has pattern of selecting vendors based on cost optimization rather than security requirements, similar to past vendor security failures. Compromises low-cost vendor matching this profile, knowing organization will unconsciously grant trust and access consistent with past vulnerable relationships.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizations unconsciously recreate familiar vendor relationship patterns even when these patterns led to past security failures. Repetition compulsion in vendor selection creates predictable vulnerability profile that sophisticated attackers exploit through vendor compromise.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Supply chain attacks targeting organizations with history of vendor security incidents, where attackers compromise new vendors matching same low-security-investment profile as past problematic relationships
